channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Militias in Libya Advance on ISIS Stronghold of Surt With Separate Agendas
item.media:description: Libyan militia fighters firing an artillery cannon at Islamic State militants near Surt, Libya, last year.
item.description: The battle for the coastal city, which could harbor as many as 6,500 Islamic State fighters, is at the center of a fractious struggle by rival groups for control of Libya’s future.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Syria, Facing Deadline, Allows Limited Aid to Besieged Town of Daraya
item.media:description: Vehicles from the International Committee of the Red Cross and the United Nations entered the rebel-held Syrian town of Daraya, southwest of the capital, Damascus, on Wednesday for the first time since 2012.
item.description: Aid groups and opposition figures said the delivery was minimal and appeared intended to forestall a United Nations commitment to begin airdrops of food.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Treasury Imposes Sanctions on North Korea, Cutting Access to Banks
item.media:description: North Koreans in Pyongyang cheered a bomb test in January.
item.description: The Treasury, employing techniques used on Iran, wants to cut Pyongyang off from the American financial system with what are known as secondary sanctions.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL CORKERY

item.title: Trans-Pacific Partnership Supporters Pin Hopes on Lame-Duck Vote
item.media:description: President Tran Dai Quang of Vietnam with President Obama during his visit to Vietnam in May.
item.description: The certainty of Mr. Obama’s successor rejecting the agreement has T.P.P. advocates pushing for a vote before 2017.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Xi Jinping, China’s President, Unexpectedly Meets With North Korean Envoy
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, right, in Beijing. He is said to have told a North Korean envoy that China was seeking “calm” on the Korean Peninsula.
item.description: The meeting is believed to have been the first between the Chinese president and a senior North Korean official since 2013.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Britons, Feeling Apart From E.U., May Make It So With ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Delegates for the populist U.K. Independence Party, or UKIP, during their spring conference in Llandudno, Wales, in February. The party has pushed to leave the European Union.
item.description: Underneath the campaign’s theatrics lie questions of identity: Have Britons, many of whom see the European Union as a money-sucking abstraction, ever felt like part of Europe?
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: German Vote on Armenian Genocide Riles Tempers, and Turkey
item.media:description: Turkish-Armenian women searching for the graves of relatives in the Armenian cemetery in Istanbul last year, the 100th anniversary of the genocide.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Germany’s Parliament is expected to approve a resolution on Thursday declaring the mass killing of Armenians by Ottoman Turks in 1915-16 to be genocide.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Reviled by Many Russians, Mikhail Gorbachev Still Has Lots to Say
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev at his office in Moscow last month. “I keep saying that Russia needs more democracy,” he said.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Gorbachev helped bring an end to the Soviet Union, and some say he should be tried for it. He shrugs it off. “It is freedom of expression,” he says.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: First Residents Return to Fort McMurray After Wildfire
item.description: Four weeks after fires hit Fort McMurray, Alberta, officials issued a long list of safety warnings and faced questions about whether the gradual return was premature.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Shabab Attack on Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia, Kills Over a Dozen
item.media:description: A victim of an assault by militants was carried away from the Ambassador Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Wednesday.
item.description: The Shabab militant organization claimed responsibility for the attack by gunmen and a car bomb, directed at a popular hotel in Mogadishu, the capital.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and MOHAMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Zimbabwean Pushed From Mugabe’s Inner Circle Now Challenges It
item.media:description: Joice Mujuru served as a vice president under Robert Mugabe and was once so close to him that she considered herself to be like a daughter.
item.description: Joice Mujuru, a celebrated freedom fighter who was ousted from the governing party, vows to seek power on her own in the 2018 elections.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Foreign Minister Castigates Canadian Reporter for Rights Question
item.description: The minister, Wang Yi, browbeat a journalist who asked about the Chinese government’s detention of human rights advocates and a Canadian couple accused of spying.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rich Defendants’ Request to Judges: Lock Me Up in a Gilded Cage
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab, a gold trader facing trial in New York, in December 2013. A judge is considering his request to avoid pretrial detention by paying for armed guards, wearing a GPS device and posting a $50 million bond.
item.description: Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader facing trial in New York, is asking the courts to let him avoid pretrial detention by posting a $50 million bond and financing his own armed guards.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Uber Turns to Saudi Arabia for $3.5 Billion Cash Infusion
item.media:description: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of Uber, views the Middle East as an increasingly important overseas market.
item.description: The ride-hailing company said the investment by Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund was part of the most recent financing round that valued the company at $62.5 billion.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Rhodes Scholarship Program to Expand
item.media:description: A statue of Cecil Rhodes on the facade of Oriel College in Oxford, England. In January, after a campaign to remove the sculpture, Oriel said the statue would remain, but promised to “provide a clear historical context to explain why it is there.”
item.description: The expansion, which will open the program to students from nine countries and territories, comes as Cecil Rhodes’s legacy faces withering scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Muslim Killed by Indian Mob Had Beef in His Home, New Report Says
item.media:description: Relatives mourned Muhammad Ikhlaq after he was beaten to death last year in Bisara, India.
item.description: The latest report contradicted a finding that meat found in the man’s home was from a goat and not from a cow — the holy Hindu symbol he was accused of eating.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Saudi Court Sentences 14 to Death in Attacks on Security Forces
item.description: The men were arrested a few years ago, when protests by members of Saudi Arabia’s Shiite minority roiled the Qatif area of Eastern Province.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Letter From Europe: Drawing Lessons From the Scottish Referendum as E.U. Vote Nears
item.media:description: Douglas Alexander in 2015. He is campaigning for Britain’s continued membership in the European Union.
item.description: With Britain deciding whether to leave the European Union, a Labour Party notable who lost his seat after Scotland’s failed independence push offers hard-won advice.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: E.U. Chides Poland for Failing to Uphold Rule of Law
item.media:description: An anti-government demonstration in Warsaw in May.
item.description: The opinion by the bloc’s executive arm, the European Commission, reflected increasing alarm in the West about Warsaw’s commitment to democracy.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: 20,000 Iraqi Children Are Trapped by Falluja Battle, U.N. Warns
item.media:description: Women and children who fled their homes near Fallujah took shelter in Garma, Iraq, last month.
item.description: Few families have been able to leave the city, where Islamic State fighters are under siege by government forces.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS SCHORZMAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Mitsubishi Materials Apologizes to Chinese World War II Laborers
item.description: Three survivors of its predecessor company’s mines will each receive about $15,000 under an agreement intended to be used as a template for future settlements.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Reprint of Hitler’s ‘Mein Kampf’ Tests German Law
item.media:description: Historic copies of Adolf Hitler’s “Mein Kampf” at the Institute for Contemporary History in Munich in January.
item.description: Prosecutors are weighing charges against the publisher. While the work is widely available on the internet, a government-approved annotated version is the only one legal in Germany.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Prosecutors Investigate Beijing Police Over Death of Detained Man
item.media:description: Police officers questioning a man in Tiananmen Square in Beijing on March 2, 2015. It is rare for prosecutors in China to investigate the police for excessive violence.
item.description: The death of the man, Lei Yang, a 29-year-old environmentalist and father of a newborn daughter, was widely discussed online in China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Tilaurakot Journal: India and Nepal in Not-Very-Enlightened Spat Over Buddha’s Childhood Home
item.media:description: An archaeological dig at Tilaurakot in Nepal. The site is part of a tug-of-war between India and Nepal over Buddhist history.
item.description: The archaeological tug of war has rumbled for more than a century, but with Buddhist history becoming serious business, the debate has taken on new urgency.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: World’s Longest and Deepest Rail Tunnel, Through Swiss Alps, Opens
item.description: The current four-hour trip between the major economic hubs of Zurich and Milan will be cut by about an hour.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Ding Zilin, Founder of Tiananmen Mothers, is Silenced by Chinese Police
item.media:description: Ding Zilin, a retired university professor and co-founder of the Tiananmen Mothers, at her Beijing home in 2009 in front of a portrait of her 17-year-old son, Jiang Jielian, who was among the hundreds killed when troops moved in to end democracy protests in Tiananmen Square on the night of June 3-4, 1989.
item.description: Each year as the anniversary of her son’s death during the democracy protests approaches, the authorities guard Ms. Ding’s home in Beijing, turning away journalists and other visitors.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Black Box From Missing EgyptAir Flight 804 Is Said to Be Detected
item.media:description: A French soldier aboard an aircraft searching in May for debris from the crashed EgyptAir Flight 804 over the Mediterranean Sea.
item.media:credit: Alexandre Groyer/French Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The retrieval of the plane’s data recorders would shed light on why it crashed into the Mediterranean on May 19, killing all 66 on board.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: With Heart Surgery Done, Nawaz Sharif to Return to Pakistan
item.media:description: Supporters of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan praying for his recovery in Multan, Pakistan, on Tuesday.
item.description: Prime Minister Sharif, 66, underwent four bypasses on Tuesday at a hospital in London, his second open-heart operation over the past five years.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: On the Runway: In Rio, Louis Vuitton Store Robbed Days After Lavish Show
item.description: Thieves broke into the brand’s Ipanema store and stole handbags worth thousands of dollars.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: North Korea Applauds Donald Trump’s Threat to Pull Troops From South
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at his office tower in New York. He has said that he is willing to talk directly to the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, an unsettling notion for South Korean officials.
item.description: A ruling party newspaper in North Korea has praised Mr. Trump for suggesting that the South might lose its American troops unless it pays more for them.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Abe to Delay Putting Japan’s Sales Tax Increase Into Effect
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, center, with members of his cabinet at a plenary session of the House of Representatives on Wednesday in Tokyo.
item.description: While the prime minister’s decision was widely expected, it amounts to an acknowledgment that the country’s economy remains fragile.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: State of the Art: Why the World Is Drawing Battle Lines Against American Tech Giants
item.description: European efforts to rein in the largest American tech companies are only a taste of what countries like Brazil, India and China are likely to do.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Thai Officials Find 40 Dead Cubs in Freezer at Tiger Temple
item.media:description: The carcasses of 40 tiger cubs were found at Wat Pha Luang Ta Bua, a Buddhist site widely known as the Tiger Temple, in Kanchanaburi, Thailand.
item.description: Wildlife officials are investigating whether the Tiger Temple, a controversial tourist attraction, was trafficking in tiger parts, which the temple denies.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: What in the World: The Y’s and Wherefores of How Cubans Name Their Children
item.description: Many born during the Cold War were given first names beginning with Y. Experts differ as to whether it was in tribute to the Soviet Union, or in rebellion.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Airport Near Everest Is Its Own Perilous Adventure
item.media:description: A plane landing at Tenzing-Hillary Airport in Lukla, Nepal. The airport, the closest one to Mount Everest, challenges pilots with its weather and short, sloped runway.
item.description: Planes heading to Tenzing-Hillary Airport in Lukla, Nepal, often have to deal with high wind and thick fog. Then pilots face a short, sloping runway.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: What in the World: On Offer in China: ‘Fried Swarm’ and Other Tasty Translations
item.description: A stroll through just about any Chinese city will reveal the joys of eating in a country with language significantly far from English.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: ‘Let’s All Become Jews’
item.media:description: Yvan Attal
item.media:credit: Colin McConnell/Toronto Star via Getty Images
item.description: A new comedy about anti-Semitism questions what it means to be Jewish in France.
item.dc:creator: PAMELA DRUCKERMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Soup Kitchens of Athens
item.media:description: Greek pensioners demonstrating against pension cuts in front of the the Greek Parliament in Athens.
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.description: The cost of austerity in Greece is human misery.
item.dc:creator: YANIS VAROUFAKIS

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on How to Survive Airport Lines
item.description: Beware of unspecified additional fees.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
